description: Late Latin; equivalent to interrogate + -ory (“pertaining to”), or more distantly inter- + rogatory.

adjectives.description: interrogatory (comparative more interrogatory, superlative most interrogatory)

entries.meaning: (law) A formal question submitted to opposing party to answer, generally governed by court rule.
examples: If those attempts are unsuccessful, the attorney requesting the interrogatories may file a motion for sanctions with the court. The sanctions range from attorney fees to prohibiting the nonanswering party from presenting or defending claims.

But when he found that some of his interrogatories were evaded, and others answered undecisively, the look of gentleness which he had assumed, vanished, and his brow wore the cloud of disappointment and of anger.
